Description: Terracotta figure of Aphrodite Anadyomene. The upper part of a crouching Aphrodite of anadyomene type, wringing her hair. She is naked and she rests her left elbow on her raised left knee. Both hands are raised; from the right hand a lock of hair falls onto her shoulder, another lock runs from her left hand along her forearm. At the back the hair is more fully delineated, with the wrung hair following the pattern shown at the front, with some strands hanging down the back of her neck. Her hair is parted in the centre and is surmounted by a high diadem. Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt with traces back and front of a white dressing which has crystallized in places during burial; the coating was painted an orange-pink colour.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Comparanda. Close in pose: Besques 1992: no. D 4486, said to be from Antinoopolis or Lower Egypt, dated beginning of the second century bc; Fischer 1994: no. 922, dated Roman Imperial, based on a Hellenistic original; LIMC ii (2): pl. 166: Aphrodite 190, from the Fayum; Pingiatoglou 1993: no. 67; Petrie Museum uc45412 (faience). Near: Breccia 1934: no. 3; Habachi 1957: pl. xlic, from Bilbeis in the Delta; Hilton Price 1897: 398, no. 3302, from Bubastis. Bibliog. Fischer 1994: nos 921 and 922.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3352)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
